"Being in a serious relationship is not enough to protect young gay men from infection with HIV, new research suggests.
 
 In fact, a study by researchers at Northwestern University found that young gay couples are six times more likely to have unprotected sex than casual partners.
 
 The researchers noted that gay men account for nearly 70 percent of all new HIV/AIDS diagnoses among adolescents and young adults in the United States. A recent study by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also found that the majority of new HIV infections occur within committed relationships."

 More at For Gay Men, Serious Relationships Still Harbor Risks for HIV - Yahoo! News

He immediately recommended one. There was no discussion of possible risks in my life, or how to avoid the virus.
 
 Gay men in serious relationships who are involved in the gay community, may very well be compelled into taking the test, simply out of a sense of community duty. AIDS organizations have long been connected to the gay community. Heterosexuals already in the middle of a serious relationship won't see the need to be tested unless and until they have symptoms which may first appear years after being infected with HIV, or unless of course, they feel they can't trust their partner.

 Gay men who are out and proud in serious relationships are more likely to be involved in cultural and political aspects of the gay community. HIV/AIDS activism and organizing was started up by the gay male community. These put a focus on testing. Awareness and testing campaigns specifically target gay men in places we gather and in our media. AIDS organizations often provide social support and information for the gay community itself, which is aside from HIV/AIDS. However, this still represents another possible opportunity for a gay male to be tested. I'm trying to explain the social realities of the gay community of which you may not be aware, through no fault of your own, but simply because you are not gay and have not been involved in the community like myself. Personally I've never met a heterosexual who had been tested for HIV, despite being sexually active, despite not taking precautions. I know gay men who have. The ones who were tended to be at least somewhat out and considered themselves part of a gay community, or knew of someone who had AIDS or had been somehow involved with an AIDS group(even if it was for other purposes as I mentioned). The likelihood of a group being tested, is relevant to a degree, when looking at new diagnosis one group compared to another.
 
 It's like a regular part of gay life: repeat HIV a... [AIDS Educ Prev. 1997] - PubMed result
 
 There are many complicated factors at work here. I'm not disputing the actual numbers of new diagnosis, I'm just saying it's not the whole story in regards to any individual's risk, and it only looks at those who decide to be tested. One can throw around large numbers for shock value, but each possible aspect of what's behind the numbers is also worth discussing. This was one no one else on thread was bringing up, so I thought I'd add it.

Actually, what makes you more at risk in any case, whether gay, straight, using drugs, prostitution is not using a condom or a clean needle. You're making overly-broad analogies.

It's not "faff", that's part of the story behind the numbers of new diagnosis. There is a different culture, when it comes to getting tested, between gay and straight. It leads to more opportunities for gays to receive the test.
 
 
 
 I don't expect, nor do I need a "thank you" from anyone. I certainly don't seek one from you. You have too high an opinion of yourself.
 
 
 
 Everything is more sophisticated and nuanced, especially in this case. I guess I over-estimated your desire or ability to understand. Actually, what makes you more at risk in any case, whether gay, straight, using drugs, prostitution is not using a condom or a clean needle. You're making overly-broad analogies.

 Culture ? Thats a joke isnt it?
 The 'culture' is the same ' culture' of injecting junkies, prostitutes...they are the highest risk groups .
 Nothing is ' sophisticated and nuanced' Provocateur about being in HIV high risk group.
 What the hell are you talking about ' over broad analogies' ?
 Of course what makes you at risk is not using condoms or clean needles ...and it seems more of you little darlings are leaving the condom off than heteros doesnt it?
 Culture, sophisticated? What a laugh!

 I showed how there is a culture of extremely high levels of testing, specifically among the gay male community. Therefore your references to drug users and prostitutes where the same culture does not exist, are nothing more than a diversion to my argument about higher levels of regular testing leading to more new diagnosis. Again, there are many ways to determine an individual's or a group's risk level. Here, we are merely talking about counting new reported diagnosis. Speaking of levels of those who actually get tested or are likely to get tested for a wily disease, which often shows no symptoms is relevant. This is my last word on the subject. I'm otherwise wasting my time.

 Gays are not at the high risk of contacting HIV because they are being tested more....they are in a high risk group because so many of them are testing positive.
 A ' culture' of extremely high levels of testing?
 What they need is a ' culture' of keeping it in their trousers and/or using condoms if they cant.
